system.description: An external light source and a Presence DR10 test are needed to activate the prism. Its light may shine on up to two creatures healing d6 HP. For the next hour one of them lowers all test DRs by -2. If the test is failed they suffer d4 damage and their armor or a weapon is destroyed. You can use the prism twice per day.
You may use powers while wearing medium armor.

system.abilities:
Painfully average, you adjust no abilities. Roll a d8 on the weapons table. Roll a d4 on the armor table but reroll if you receive heavy armor. You begin with two of the following:

 

  1. The Blade of you Ancestors
  2. ‘Poltroon’ the Court Jester
  3. Barbarister the Incredible Horse
  4. Hamfund the Squire
  5. The Snake-Skin Gift
  6. Horn of the Schleswig Lords!

 

Things were going so well, until… (d6)

  1. your Wästland palace was reduced to rubble.
  2. your caravan kingdom of Tveland fell into penury.
  3. King Fathmu IX's brother Zigmund, your father, was murdered.
  4. the southern empire of Südglans sank into the sea.
  5. Anthelia demanded a gift of royal blood
  6. two young princes were kidnapped west of Bergen Chrypt and disappeared into the black crevasse of the eastern slopes.
system.description: Bowed down only by the memories of your own lost glory, you could never submit to anyone else. Not you, of noble blood! (Not that you expect any of these peons to understand the depths of your sorrow.)
system.startingRolls:
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Wretched Royalty Items,2
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Things were going so well until,1

system.description: d2 creatures regain d10 HP each.
You can draw nourishment from soil, but normal food makes you sick. You smell like mushrooms.

You may open and read from this book once a day. Your enemy must make a DR12 test to prevent this. If they fail D2 Berserker-slayers (see page 60) appear from the depths of a forgotten dimension of blood. Roll a D6.

On a 1–4 these creatures fight alongside you. On a 5–6 they turn on you, attempting to kill you and destroy the book. After the battle they return to their imprisonment.

An expensive sandalwood box bound in snakeskin. It contains a seemingly ordinary dagger, wrapped in silk. The dagger does d4 damage but on a 1 the target dies immediately of deadly poison weeping from the blade.
May function as 5 meals.

system.abilities:
Built like a Bull, roll 3d6+2 for Strength. Not a Bright Spark, roll 3d6-1 for Agility and Presence. Normal Agility tests are DR14 instead of DR12, excluding defense. Illiterate; you are incapable of understanding scrolls. If you begin with one then reroll, eat it or use it as toilet paper. You also begin with one of the following:

  1. Crumpled Monster Mask
  2. The Brown Scimitar of Galgenbeck
  3. Wizard Teeth
  4. Old Sigûrd’s sling
  5. Ancient Gore-Hound
  6. The Shoe of Death's Horse

 

EARLIEST MEMORIES, D6

  1. A burnt-black building in Sarkash. Your home?
  2. A derelict rotting ship rolling endlessly across a grey sea.
  3. A brothel in Schleswig. Quite a friendly environment.
  4. Sleeping with dogs in the corner of an inn, waiting for someone to return.
  5. Following an army in eastern Wästland.
  6. Suckling a wolf in the wild of Bergen Chrypt.
system.description: You have thirty or so friends who never let you down: YOUR TEETH. Disloyal, deranged or simply uncontrollable, any group that didn’t boot you out you left anyway. But your parliament of teeth—enormous, protruding, thick and sharp—have always been your allies. Bite attack: DR10 to attack, d6 damage. You must be close to your target. 1–2 on d6 chance the enemy gets a free attack.

name: Nine Violet Signs Unknot the Storm

system.description: Produce d2 lightning bolts dealing d6 damage each.
Illiterate; you are incapable of understanding scrolls. If you begin with one then reroll, eat it or use it as toilet paper.
Once per day release a blare from this dented old trumpet and test Presence DR12. One creature may make their next non-combat test an automatic success.
Holds 10 normal-sized items.
A creature becomes invisible for d6 rounds or until it is damaged, attacking/defending with DR6.
Attacks with DR10 (bite d6).

When worn, thorns pierce your flesh (d2 damage) and you Perceive All (-4DR to your next test and ignore the next two attacks to hit you as you weave aside). To regain the effect you must crown yourself anew. The damage steps up by one each time (d2 to d4 to d6 etc), until after a night’s rest.
1 day.
Ammo for a sling.

system.abilities:
Tough as wood, roll 3d6+2 Toughness. Low in protein, roll 3d6-2 Strength. Roll d6 on the weapons table and d2 on the armor table. You carry a portable laboratory and continually search for frequently expended ingredients. Daily you have the materials to create two randomly determined decoctions and can brew a total of d4 doses. If unused they lose vitality after 24 hours.

 

  1. Red Poison
  2. Ezumiels Vapor
  3. Southern Frog Stew
  4. Elixir Vitalis
  5. Spider-Owl Soup
  6. Fernor's Philtre
  7. Hyphos Enervating Snuff
  8. Black Poison

 

 (d8) Probably raised in… but may also come from

  1. calm isolation in the Sarkash dark.
  2. calm isolation in the Sarkash dark.
  3. calm isolation in the Sarkash dark.
  4. the illegal midnight markets of Schleswig.
  5. the heretic isle of Crëlut, two nautical miles east of Grift.
  6. the old frozen ruins not far from Alliáns.
  7. a little witches cottage in Galgenbeck.
  8. the runs of the Shadow King's manse, thick with memories of mushrooms and smoke.
system.description: Born of the mushroom, raised in the glade, watched by the eye of the moon in a silverblack pool.
system.startingRolls:
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Occult Herbmaster Decoctions,2
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Probably raised in,1

system.description: d4 creatures lose d8 HP each.
Allows the Occult Herbmaster to create decoctions.

Transmogrifies a child-sized rock into burnt, chewy meat. Feeds d4 famished people.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.

The MIND controls the body! Nothing is good or bad but thinking makes it so including calories and protein. Wearing this belt means you feel no hunger and only need to drink water to regain HP when resting. Wearing it for more than d4 days causes you to collapse. It takes a day to regain its power.
An ever-shifting Tablet of Ochre Obscurity is tattooed on your flesh. Roll each morning which tablet it is. The tablet can only be used once per day but automatically succeeds.
Who wouldn’t forgo fisticuffs for a grappling hook?
You can escape any bindings, and fit through tiny spaces. Tests involving flexibility are -4 DR.

system.abilities:
Insightful, roll 3d6+2 for Presence. Frail, roll 3d6-2 for Strength. Roll a d8 on the weapons table and may use Powers while wearing medium armor. You begin with one of the following:

 

  1. Sacred shepherd’s crook
  2. Stolen Mitre
  3. List of Sins
  4. The Blasphemous Nechrubel Bible
  5. Stones taken from Thel-Emas' Lost Temple
  6. (Wrong Jesus) Crucifix

 

Unholy Origins

  1. Galgenbeck, near the cathedral of the Two-Headed Basilisks.
  2. Massacred Alliáns cult, sole survivor.
  3. The crypts of Grift.
  4. Temple ruins in the Valley if the Unfortunate Undead.
  5. One of the many Graven-Tosk thief-tunnels.
  6. Secret Bergen Chrypt church.
system.description: Hunted by the Two-Headed Basilisks of the One True Faith, this heretic can be found raving in ruins, traipsing endlessly down dusty roads and desecrating cathedrals by night.
A creature of your choice gets +d6 on one roll (damage, test, etc).
A creature of your choice is confused for 10 minutes.
Every time you use an omen there is a 50% chance it is not spent.
15 feet.
Bite attack: DR10 to attack, d6 damage. You must be close to your target. 1–2 on d6 chance the enemy gets a free attack.
Presence DR14 to spot, d8 damage.
Dextrous: Agility tests, including defence, are DR10.

system.abilities:
Name your god ... (3d10)

  1. Acrophoe | Beacon | of blood
  2. Elioch | Bearer | of death
  3. Ekk | Bride | of decay
  4. Ghzat | Child | of flies
  5. Gnost | Herald | of impotence
  6. Häil | King | of panic
  7. Kvera | Lady | of rot
  8. Malais | Prince | of rust
  9. Varkka | Queen | of unease
  10. Öde | Song | of the flesh

 

Abilities

  • Obsessed, 3d6+2 for Presence.
  • Weak through lack of care for bodily functions, 3d6-2 for Toughness.
  • Roll d4 on the weapon table and a d2 on the Armour table.
  • You are literate and can use scrolls, but must pass a DR12 Presence test when encountering them not to immediately attempt to destroy them as words of false gods. If you start with a scroll, consider that you passed the test.
  • Roll randomly for two gifts from your dead god.

 

Two gifts (d8)

  1. BLOOD TELLS - A flagellant, you regularly beat yourself to awaken your lost god. If you inflict d3 HP of damage to yourself prior to combat, you gain +2 to a number of rolls equal to the HP lost.
  2. LORD OF NOTHING - You wear a bizarre arrangement of garments and scraps that make you look like the parody of a king or queen. Still, you gain +2 to rolls to impress the easily fooled.
  3. SMELL OF DECAY - Not only is your god dead, but their odour of decay pervades you. Tests to defend against attacks have a +2 bonus due to the gut-wrenching stench.
  4. INCOHERENT SOPHISTIC BABBLE - Concentrate to babble an ungodly litany. So disconcerting is this chant that those who hear it must pass a DR10 Presence test or lose their next action.
  5. ICHOR OF ROT - The foul fluids of your god’s rot run from your hands- a black stigmata. As an DR12 attack you can wipe your hands on the bare skin of your assailants, who must then pass a DR12 Toughness test or descend into frothing spasms for two turns.
  6. MY BODY, A VESSEL - Your god may be dead, but what is death to a god? Once a day you may allow the ghost of your god to enter your flesh and reveal a truth. Ask the GM one yes/no question that they must answer truthfully. The god then departs, leaving you weakened and frail.
  7. IN DEATH I LIVE - When you die, make a DR14 Presence test. If you pass, your god refuses you into the afterlife and you recover with 1HP. If you fail, your body is consumed in holy flames.
  8. EYES OF HOLY FIRE - Your pupils burn with the soul of your lord. Once per combat you may make an attack (DR10), as fire spurts from your eyes, d6 damage. You are left blinded for the rest of the fight.
system.description: You hear voices in your head, telling you what to do. Or at least you think you do. You are the prophet of a god; only your god is dead, slain by the Basilisk SHE within the wretched peaks of the Bergen Chrypt. Now no one wants to hear the words of your god. But you can still hear them. Day and night. Like hot wires through your brain.
system.startingRolls:
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Name your god... (1),1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Name your god... (2),1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Name your god... (3),1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Gifts From Your Dead God,2

system.description: Your fangs (d6) crit on a natural 19 as well as a 20. On a crit, all enemies test Morale.
Hover for Presence+d10 rounds.
10 nails, hammer, small saw, tongs.
You are literate, but only in dead languages, and cannot use scrolls. Instead, you can intuitively use one randomly rolled Power. The Power changes each dawn, or dusk (pick one).

This amalgamation of sown, hairy gutsacks feature extruding bone pipes for you to blow on. When doing so, listeners of your choosing are filled with unearthly hunger, as if they hadn’t eaten for a week.
A flagellant, you regularly beat yourself to awaken your lost god. If you inflict d3 HP of damage to yourself prior to combat, you gain +2 to a number of rolls equal to the HP lost.
A ball of fire hits d2 creatures dealing d8 damage per creature.
Just way too many. You cannot be attacked from surprise. You can spend a use of your Powers to leave an eye behind, and spy on a remote area. If anyone squishes the eye, you take d2 damage.
One hand replaced with rusting hook (d6 damage).
Your bony scalp (d6) acts as a weapon and a shield: -1 damage and you may choose to ignore all damage from one attack. The skull will heal in d6 days.
Your bony scalp (d6) acts as a weapon and a shield: -1 damage and you may choose to ignore all damage from one attack. The skull will heal in d6 days.

name: Creature Shape - Flayed and Dripping Wolf

system.description:
• Ferocious, attacks are DR10.
  • Your fangs (d6) crit on a natural 19 as well as a 20. On a crit, all enemies test Morale.
  • Slick from blood, -d2 incoming damage.
Twice per day use your wisdom, knowledge, advice and inner calm to bring clarity to a creature of your choice. The DR of the next test they undertake is lowered by 4.

• Fast and flying, defence is DR10.
  • Make two attacks per round with your claws (d4).
  • Your bony scalp (d6) acts as a weapon and a shield: -1 damage and you may choose to ignore all damage from one attack. The skull will heal in d6 days.
Toughness DR14 or -d6 HP and blinded for one hour.
You carry an aura of unnatural charm everywhere you go, capable of unsettling foes and calming friends, spend a use of your daily Powers to add or subtract d6 to any Morale check.
d5 creatures fall asleep for one hour unless they succeed a DR14 test.

Fast and flying, defence is DR10.

Make two attacks per round with your claws (d4).
What use are maps when the substance of causality itself is open to you? You know the right way with a DR8 Presence test.
Tiny. Agility tests, including defence, are DR8.

Mends or breaks a normal-sized item, mundane or otherwise, including armor (increase/ decrease one tier) and weapons.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.

• Tiny: Agility tests, including defence, are DR8.
  • Your bite (d4) carries disease, victims test DR14 Presence or attack their closest ally, until either is dead.
Make two attacks per round with your claws (d4).
Normal Agility tests are DR14 instead of DR12, excluding defence.
You find all traps in your path for 2d10 minutes.

system.abilities:
Mental Focus, roll 3d6+2 Presence. Too Much Reading! Roll 3d6-2 Strength. Ruthless Inquisition: test Presence DR 14 to tear through others’ deceptions and delusions. Enough of these LIES! Roll d6 on the weapon table and d2 on the armor table. You begin with one Tablet of Ochre Obscurity and one of the following:

 

  1. THORNS OF COMPREHENSION
  2. HEGELIAN OWL
  3. PRISM OF AMBIGUITY
  4. FLUTE OF TOSK
  5. BASH OF THE STYLITE
  6. MARKED BY OBSCURITY
system.description: The road an unreasoning maze, every temple soaked in blood, each destination drenched in gloom; you once thought that cold analysis might tame Fate itself, now that dream of reason has decayed to shifting madness and only the cold remains.
system.startingRolls:
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Forlorn Philosopher Items,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,The Tablets of Ochre Obscurity,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,The Roots of your Dejection,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,The dejection of your Roots,1

system.description: Cranking this stringed thing of wood and gore emits a droning sound that hurts the ears of creatures that fail a Presence test against DR12. The first round played, it deals d2 damage, increasing to a d4 and beyond on subsequent rounds.
Sealed bottle, d10 damage.
Translucent oil, must be dabbed right into the eye. Heals infection and gives +2 on Presence tests for d4 hours.

Using Pure Logic you can deduce the nature of any traps or mechanisms within 30 feet or of any Powers used within 60 feet.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.
-1 damage. You may choose to ignore all damage from one attack but shield breaks.
Fur, padded cloth, leather, etc.

Roll d4+2 for omens. Say something cryptic every time you use one.

 

[Edit the Omen Rolls field on your class Details tab.]
Its head a hook of human bone inscribed with overlapping anti-prayers. This crook hooks through other worlds. Staff does 2d4 damage except to faithless humans.
Concentrate to babble an ungodly litany. So disconcerting is this chant that those who hear it must pass a DR10 Presence test or lose their next action.
Toughness DR12 or d10 damage. 3 doses.
One creature, dead for no more than a week, is awakened with terrible memories.
30 feet.
Your bite (d4) carries disease, victims test DR14 Presence or attack their closest ally, until either is dead.

name: Stones taken from Thel-Emas’ Lost Temple

system.description: Cast the stones on the ground. Their pattern reveals if danger lurks in an adjacent room. The stones can lie. The priest tests Presence DR10 to see if they are true but after failing they cannot test again until the sun has set.

The target begins to doubt it is real. Attacking and defending against it is -2 DR (+2 DR for affected PCs).

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.
All creatures within 30 feet lose a total of 4d10 HP.
One creature suffocates for d6 rounds, losing d4 HP per round.
When strummed, the sound of this axe-shaped (d8 damage) instrument makes the Strength and Presence score of anyone hearing it swap scores for the next d6 days. Repeated listening has no effect.
Summon (d6): 1-3 d4 skeletons, 4-6 d4 zombies.
Light or pitch black for 3d10 minutes.
The dagger does d4 damage but on a 1 the target dies immediately of deadly poison weeping from the blade.
You wear a bizarre arrangement of garments and scraps that make you look like the parody of a king or queen. Still, you gain +2 to rolls to impress the easily fooled.

You carry a portable laboratory and continually search for frequently expended ingredients. Daily you have the materials to create two randomly determined decoctions and can brew a total of d4 doses. If unused they lose vitality after 24 hours.

 

  1. Red Poison
  2. Ezumiels Vapor
  3. Southern Frog Stew
  4. Elixir Vitalis
  5. Spider-Owl Soup
  6. Fernor's Philtre
  7. Hyphos Enervating Snuff
  8. Black Poison

Your god may be dead, but what is death to a god? Once a day you may allow the ghost of your god to enter your flesh and reveal a truth. Ask the GM one yes/no question that they must answer truthfully. The god then departs, leaving you weakened and frail.
Four weird teeth rattle within a blackened pouch. Before battle roll a d6 for each one. For every 6 one of your attacks deals maximum damage.

You are literate and can use scrolls, but must pass a DR12 Presence test when encountering them not to immediately attempt to destroy them as words of false gods. If you start with a scroll, consider that you passed the test.
The cursed sword Eurekia. For every swing of Eurekia roll a d6. On a 1 the squire Hamfund is slain and Eurekia vanishes forever.
All Presence and Agility tests have their DR reduced by 2 (normal tests are DR10 instead of DR12).
10 nails.

name: Creature Shape - Bear from Bergen Chrypt

system.description:
• Hulking and massive: tests for Strength and Toughness, as well as attacks, are DR10. Defence is DR14.
  • Thick hide, -d4 incoming damage.
  • Your claws and bite deal d8 damage.

This cracked tablet can be crushed to a coarse powder. If strewn upon a creature it takes d6 damage-on a 6 it chokes and dies. The tablet reappears each morning in its owner’s possession. This Power’s Presence test is harmless to the wielder, determining whether or not the powder finds the target.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.
Your snaky little digits get into pockets and pick locks with a DR8 Agility test. You also begin with lockpicks!

system.abilities:
A deal was struck (d6)

  1. In an outhouse just outside Grift.
  2. Hiding from guards in Galgenbeck.
  3. In a Wästland noble’s bedchamber.
  4. Dreaming in a disremembered ditch.
  5. In a Schleswig prison cell.
  6. Minutes from freezing to death on the way to Alliáns.

 

Abilities

  • Your amplified personality makes up for a soul bartered, roll 3d6+2 for Presence.
  • A hard life lived has you set for an early grave, roll 3d6-2 for Toughness.
  • Roll d6 on the weapon table and d3 on the armor table.
  • You carry an aura of unnatural charm everywhere you go, capable of unsettling foes and calming friends, spend a use of your daily Powers to add or subtract d6 to any Morale check.

 

Accursed Instrument (d6)

When you made your life-and-soul-altering deal, you were gifted one (1) of the following accursed instruments:

  1. Gutpipes of Destiny
  2. Hurty-Gurdy
  3. Spinal Husk
  4. The Devil's Aquifer
  5. Mouth-to-Mouth-Organ
  6. Lute of the Acute Brute
system.description: Always the bringer of unwelcome sounds, your vocation as a bard left you destitute and disreputable... until the rueful day when a being of impious character made you the deal of a lifetime. Your soul may be screaming, but your throat sings sweetly, and your purse ever sweeter. A small price to pay.
system.startingRolls:
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,A deal was struck,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Accursed Instruments,1

system.description: Move an object up to 1d10x10 feet for d6 minutes.
Once per day you may summon D2 scrolls, whose power can be used only once. Roll a d4, on a 1–2 the scrolls are sacred, on a 3–4, unclean. If the scrolls are not used before sunrise they turn to ash.
You are literate, but only in dead languages, and cannot use scrolls. Instead, you can intuitively use one randomly rolled Power. The Power changes each dawn, or dusk (pick one).
See in darkness, climb on walls for 30 minutes.

You sense the presence of living creatures within 70 feet even in adjacent rooms.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.
Your third eye allows you to read unclean scrolls at DR10.
4 days of water.

system.abilities:
First Died (d6)

  1. Clutching the body of a lover.
  2. By an arrow in the brain.
  3. Minutes after being born.
  4. At the hands of a friend.
  5. Murdered in your bed.
  6. On the back of a plague-cart.

 

Abilities

  • Weakened mind, roll 3d6-2 for Presence.
  • Bestial instincts, roll 3d6+1 for Strength and Toughness.
  • Roll d6 on the weapon and d2 on the armor table.

 

Give into the advances of your antithetical other and change your very anatomy into the likeness of its being. Shifting your bones as such occupies a single painful round. Armor and weapons are likely unusable in your new form. One (1) of the following creatures stands ever at the other side of your existence:

 

Creature shapes (d6)

  1. Murder-Plagued Rat
  2. Flayed and Dripping Wolf
  3. Boneskulled Raven
  4. Bear from Bergen Chrypt
  5. Life-and-Death-Lizard
  6. Doomsaying Monkey
system.description: You should have died, but something grabbed a hold of your soul as it seeped into the river of Death and sealed you once again in mortal flesh. Only this time the cage is not yours alone-in the currents of the afterlife your soul mingled with that of another dying creature, leaving you halved. Now you live a shared existence, locked in everlasting struggle between man and monster. You should have died.
Slick from blood, -2 incoming damage.
Splint, plate, etc.
Ferocious, attacks are DR10.
You learnt your melodies in the Otherworld. The music of your Harp gives +D4 on reaction rolls.
When attacking by surprise test Agility DR10. On a success you automatically hit once with a light one-handed weapon, dealing normal damage +3.

Your phlegm is viscous, lumpy, vile and ballistically accurate at short range. You can spit d2 times during a fight. Roll a DR8 Presence test for accuracy. Targets are blinded, retching and vomiting for d4 rounds. Anyone witnessing this—friend and foe—must make a Toughness test to not also vomit. PCs test DR10 and enemies DR12.
Scaly skin, -d2 incoming damage.
Heals d6 HP and stops infection. Can be habit-forming.
Vomit for d4 hours, pass a DR14 test or you can do nothing else.
Your pupils burn with the soul of your lord. Once per combat you may make an attack (DR10), as fire spurts from your eyes, d6 damage. You are left blinded for the rest of the fight.
In case you want to play donkeys and wagons as equipment items.
Ask three questions to a deceased creature.
Your claws and bite deal d8 damage.
Regenerate d4 HP per round.
A stinking sword you pulled from a military shit-ditch. D6 damage. DR10 attack and defence while you wield it. 1 in 6 chance a wounded enemy is smitten with potent sepsis, dying in 10 minutes.

system.abilities:
Small, roll 3d6−2 for Strength. Stealthy, all Presence and Agility tests have their DR reduced by 2 (normal tests are DR10 instead of DR12). Roll d6 on the weapon table and d2 on the armor table. You also begin with one specialty:

 

  1. Coward's Jab
  2. Filthy Fingersmith
  3. Abominable Gob Lobber
  4. Escaping Fate
  5. Excretal Stealth
  6. Dodging Death

 

The first time the Scum gets better another specialty is rolled. From the second time the Scum gets better it’s possible to reroll these two specialities or just one.
system.description: An ill star smiled upon your birth. Poverty, crime and bad parenting didn’t help either. In your community an honest day’s work was never an option. Not that you ever tried, what are you, some kind of mug? A razor blade and a moonless night are worth a week of chump-work.
You have an astounding, almost preternatural ability to hide in muck, debris and filth. When hidden in these conditions a DR16 Presence test is required to notice you.
d4 damage + infection on 1 in 6.
You can fly short distances, but cannot wear armor. Birds seem to dislike you.
Spit acid (d4, 1 in 4 chance armor is lowered one tier).
Hulking and massive: tests for Strength and Toughness, as well as attacks, are DR10. Defence is DR14.

While wearing this holy hat the priest's vile body fades, becoming hard to hit in combat (Defense DR10). If pulled over the ears outside of battle the priest becomes nearly invisible, testing stealth against DR8.
Toughness DR14 or d6 damage + blind for one hour. 3 doses.
A creature of your choice gains 2d6 extra HP for 10 rounds.
Berserk! Two attacks per round but defend with DR14. Lasts one fight. Must be snorted, causes sneezing.
Presence + 6 hours.

system.abilities:
Wise, roll 3D6+2 for Presence. Weak, roll 3D6−2 for Strength. Ordinary starting equipment plus one random scroll (sacred or unclean). Roll a D4 on the weapons table and D2 on the armor table. You also begin with one of the following:

 

  1. Master of Fate
  2. Book of Boiling Blood
  3. Speaker of Truths
  4. Initiate of the Invisible College
  5. Bard of the Undying
  6. Hawk as Weapon

 

Eldritch Origins, d6

  1. Awakening, adult, in a ritual circle underneath the northern bridge to Grift.
  2. Wandered, memoryless, from the mouth of a cavern at the cliffs of Terion.
  3. Single child survivor of an incident in the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead.
  4. Dying of plague in a Bergen Chrypt hovel, you touched something from outside.
  5. An average individual until you encountered something in a dim glade in Sarkash.
  6. Raised on a lonely island in Lake Onda. No one else has ever heard of this island and you can’t return.
system.description: The stone of your cave is one with the stars. Silence and perfection. Now the chaos of a fallen world disturbs your rituals and the caul of night grows blacker than your cavern’s gloom. Irritating!
system.startingRolls:
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,All Scrolls,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Esoteric Hermit Items,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Eldritch Origins,1

system.description: It looks normal but since finding it in an obscure crypt you are convinced this shoe came from the horse of Death himself. In your hands it hits with DR10, d4 damage. 1 in 6 chance the shoe smashes the skull, instantly killing small-to-medium sized creatures. The shoe returns to your hand like a boomerang.
You learnt your melodies in the Otherworld. The music of your Harp gives +D4 on reaction rolls.
Thick hide, -d4 incoming damage.
Bite (d6).

Painfully average, you adjust no abilities.

 

It's not much of a feat, but hey.
One creature blindly obeys a single command.

So intensely blasphemous even the Priests themselves can only peruse it once per day. When read, roll a die. 

Even result: For the rest of the day PCs heal d4 HP after just five minutes of rest.

Odd result: The priest is plagued by demon hallucinations. The DM may invent d3 things that only the Priest can see and describe them to the player as if true. This effect ends with sunrise.
Strikes primitive fear into lesser creatures like goblins, gnoums and children. While worn, they check Morale every round.
DR10 (claws/bite D4).

Sigûrd was the strongest man whose throat you ever gnawed. Woven from his long grey hair, this sling has never failed you. 2d4 damage, requires fist-sized rocks which, perhaps regrettably, are everywhere.
Pass a DR14 test or severe (and arguably fun) hallucinations for d4 hours.

• Regenerate d4 HP per round.
  • Bite (d6) or spit acid (d4, 1 in 4 chance armor is lowered one tier).
  • Scaly skin, -d2 incoming damage.
Not only is your god dead, but their odour of decay pervades you. Tests to defend against attacks have a +2 bonus due to the gut-wrenching stench.
You may speak with animals for d20 minutes.

system.abilities:
3d6 for each ability.

One hand holds 2d6 × 10 silver (s), the other holds a waterskin and d4 days worth of food. Your soul and your silver are your own and equally easy to lose. To begin with, you are what you own:

 

D6

  1. nothing
  2. nothing
  3. backpack
  4. sack
  5. small wagon or one item above of your choice
  6. donkey, not bad. Or one of the above of your choice.

 

D12

  1. rope
  2. Presence + 4 torches
  3. lantern with oil
  4. magnesium strip
  5. random unclean scroll
  6. sharp needle
  7. medicine box
  8. metal file and lockpicks
  9. bear trap
  10. bomb
  11. a bottle of red poison d4 doses
  12. silver crucifix

 

D12

  1. Elixir Vitalis (life elixir) d4 doses
  2. random sacred scroll
  3. small but vicious dog (d6+2 HP, bite d4, only obeys you)
  4. d4 monkeys that ignore but love you (d4+2 HP, punch/bite d4)
  5. exquisite perfume
  6. toolbox 10 nails, tongs, hammer, small saw and drill
  7. heavy chain
  8. grappling hook
  9. shield
  10. crowbar
  11. lard
  12. tent
system.description: In this world there are those who seek riches or redemption. Some say the apocalypse is escapable, that it might even be stopped. And there you walk in discord and despair.

This magnificent and clearly magical talking sword is foppish, unreliable and quietly despises you. It taunts your failures and, if continually disappointed, develops a 1 in 6 chance to ‘accidentally’ attack you or your companions. Deals d6+1 damage. Attack/Defence DR is 10.

When beating this drum made from a hellion’s shell, roll 2d6:

  • 6+ - Everyone except you tests Agility against DR14 or falls prone.
  • 11 - Choose d4 creatures that can hear your drumming. Their spines break like twigs. You cannot use the drum again today.
  • 12 - Your ears won’t stop ringing; you are deaf for the next 24 hours.

 

Also doubles as a shield.

You are so unpleasant, irrelevant, disgusting and vile even Death would rather avoid you if it can. On death, if there is even the slightest possibility that you survived, there is a 50% chance that you did. If successful, after 10 rounds you pop back up with d4 HP and an unlikely explanation of your escape.
Scale, mail, etc.
Holds 7 normal-sized items.

The crucifix can be used in encounters with the undead as we as lesser trolls and goblins. Check morale (add or subtract the priest's Presence modifier) to see if the creatures bow and kindly remove themselves.

• Dextrous: Agility tests, including defence, are DR10.
  • Light armor and weapons remain usable.
  • Your third eye allows you to read unclean scrolls at DR10.
Test Presence DR 14 to tear through others’ deceptions and delusions. Enough of these LIES!

The user may transform a container of liquid one of the following ways:

  • Transmute it into two doses of Red or Black Poison.
  • Create The Loathing of Vulark. The imbiber rolls a DC16 Toughness test or jumps from great heights.
  • Transform poison to water or wine.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.

The foul fluids of your god’s rot run from your hands - a black stigmata. As an DR12 attack you can wipe your hands on the bare skin of your assailants, who must then pass a DR12 Toughness test or descend into frothing spasms for two turns.

This tablet’s code literally removes a creature’s essential meaning for d4 rounds. During which enemies will not attack it, even if it attacks them first.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.

A long and accurate document cross-referenced against reality to discover unseen evil-doers. Successfu Presence DR10: A strange light surrounds evil creatures. The list's owner defends with +2 against any being discovered this way.
Play this bony mouth harp to make a broken listener instantly recover d4 HP. They cannot speak until their HP is fully recovered.

Water freezes from the air forming a 15 foot long bridge or all water within 150 feet (unfortunately excluding that within living creatures) freezes.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.

Near-imperceptible body shifts transmit a simple mind-plague which causes one creature to dance madly for d4 rounds. They may neither attack nor defend during this choreomania.

 

Made from the clay of the Valley of the Unfortunate Undead, these Ochre Tablets are Relics of a forgotten mind-cult so rare they can be sold for 100 silver.

 

Each tablet counts as a normal-sized item. If a PC fumbles an attack/defense one tablet breaks. Otherwise, they follow the same usage rules as scrolls.

 

The coded glyphs are challenging to comprehend; PCs wielding their Power must have Presence +3 (minimum) or be a Forlorn Philosopher.
Stops bleeding/infection and +d6 HP. Presence + 4 uses.

system.abilities:
Unspoken origins (d6):

  1. Caught by fishermen on the Endless sea.
  2. Accidentally summoned by cultists in Graven-Tosk.
  3. Vomited forth by a foul beast in Bergen Chrypt.
  4. Fell from the Sky near Alliáns.
  5. Hatched from an egg laid by a bog-witch in a Wästland swamp.
  6. Crawled out of a crack in the ground not far from Grift.

 

Abilities

  • Your mind and movements are alien, +1 Agility and Presence, but your bones are hollow and fragile, -2 Toughness.
  • Roll d6 on the weapon table and d2 on the armor table.
  • You are literate, but only in dead languages, and cannot use scrolls. Instead, you can intuitively use one randomly rolled Power. The Power changes each dawn, or dusk (pick one).

 

Pale One blessings (d6)

  1. THE STARS WERE RIGHT - Roll d4+2 for omens. Say something cryptic every time you use one.
  2. MEMBRANOUS WINGS - You can fly short distances, but cannot wear armor. Birds seem to dislike you.
  3. UNCOMMON CLAY - You can draw nourishment from soil, but normal food makes you sick. You smell like mushrooms.
  4. MANA FROM SOMEWHERE - Spend a use of your Powers to create food for d6 people. It is weirdly delicious, but unsettling.
  5. DIGITIGRADE LIMBS - You can escape any bindings, and fit through tiny spaces. Tests involving flexibility are -4 DR.
  6. TOO MANY EYES - Just way too many. You cannot be attacked from surprise. You can spend a use of your Powers to leave an eye behind, and spy on a remote area. If anyone squishes the eye, you take d2 damage.

 

You call yourself ... (3d20)

  1. Abhorred | Attacks | the Æther
  2. Beneath | Attracts | the Damned
  3. Clad | Awaits | the Decay
  4. Errant | Blackens | the Dust
  5. Familiar | Chimes | the Eye
  6. Giant | Covers | the Face
  7. Hidden | Dances | the Flesh
  8. Lyrical | Denies | the Flies
  9. Maniacal | Descends | the Flower
  10. Nameless | Drowns | the Knives
  11. Obscene | Echoes | the Moon
  12. Painful | Proffers | the Mountain
  13. Reposed | Quivers | the Plague
  14. Skeletal | Rains | the Prayer
  15. Strong | Reflects | the Rats
  16. Sudden | Returns | the Saint
  17. Unaware | Seals | the Sea
  18. Unknowing | Submits | the Stranger
  19. Vitriolic | Weaves | the Truth
  20. Westward | Wilts | the Void
system.description:
You lurk on the fringes of settlements,
observing, perhaps judging, but rarely interacting. You are fundamentally other, and belong nowhere. You’ve had bouts of incoherent madness and self-destructive rages, but mostly you simply wait, in solitary resignation, for that which is inevitable.
system.startingRolls:
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Unspoken origins,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,Pale One blessings,1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,You call yourself... (1),1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,You call yourself... (2),1
morkborg.mork-borg-tables,You call yourself... (3),1

system.description: When you die, make a DR14 Presence test. If you pass, your god refuses you into the afterlife and you recover with 1HP. If you fail, your body is consumed in holy flames.
d4 doses (heals d6 HP and removes infection)
In case you want to play donkeys and wagons as equipment items.
Toughness DR12 or -d10 HP.

The horn of a beelzebubonic creature from the deepest depths of the Endless Sea. When blown, the lungs of your enemies fill with seawater, should they fail a Toughness test against DR14; a round must be spent expelling it before doing anything else.
Once per combat, when a creature dies, you may play this bone flute’s Echoing Fugue. This deals an ‘echo’ of the fatal damage to a random enemy in the vicinity.
Spend a use of your Powers to create food for d6 people. It is weirdly delicious, but unsettling.
